searchHelp.title: Otsingu abiinfo
searchHelp.help1: Sisesta märksõna(d) kiireks otsinguks kõigist andmetabelitest. Suur- ja väiketähti ei eristata, pimesümbolina (wildcard) kasutada tärni
searchHelp.help2: Mitme märksõna korral otsitakse vasteid, kus esineb vähemalt üks otsitavatest. Et märksõna kindlasti tulemustes sisalduks, lisa selle ette '+'. Kui soovid mõne termini välistada, siis kasuta märksõna ees '-'. Näiteks:
searchHelp.help3: Mitmesõnalise väljendi otsimiseks ümbritse see jutumärkidega; sama tee ka siis kui otsitav sisaldab erimärke, nagu '-' ja '+', nt

help4.prepend: Kiirotsingut saab kasutada ka detailsemate pärigute jaoks, kuid selleks tuleb teada andmebaasi väljade nimetusi. Nt päring
help4.append: otsib kirjeid, kus stratigraafiaks on määratud Burtnieki lade. NB! sellise otsingu puhul tehakse vahet suur- ja väiketähtedel ('asaphus' and 'Asaphus' ei ole samad), abiks on pimesümbol (*).

prototype_alert.title: This is GeoCASe 2.0 interface.
prototype_alert.text: Please report problems in GitHub. The old portal is accessible at: http://old.geocase.eu.

fossils.title: Fossiilid
fossils.text: Kivistised on kunagi elanud organismide jäänused või jäljed. Nende hulka kuuluvad luud, kestad, urud ja aeg-ajalt mineraliseerunud pehmed kehad.

minerals.title: Mineraalid
minerals.text: Mineraalidel on kindel keemiline koostis ja kristallstruktuur. Need on kõigi kivimite aluseks.

rocks.title: Kivimid
rocks.text: Kivimid ja setted moodustavad kindla Maa. Need võivad olla magmaatilised, settelised või moondelised.

meteorites.title: Meteoriidid
meteorites.text: Meteoriidid on Maale langenud kosmosekivimid, mis koosnevad samadest mineraalidest nagu maised kivimid.

footer.title: GeoCASe: Euroopa Geokogude Portaal
footer.collab_html: GeoCASe 2.0 on valminud CETAF Earth Science Group'i ühistööl.
footer.created_html: Portaali tarkvara on loodud ja majutatud TalTech ning MfN poolt.

tutorial.html:
How to use the GeoCASe portal

Click here for the GeoCASe 2.0  comprehensive user guide that explains how to use the features and how to cite data, but here is a summary:.

Search

  • Search results are always represented in three tabs:
    • Data table
    • Images contained in the records found
    • Map of localities for results that have coordinates 

Filters / Facettes

     

Specimen types

Shortcuts on the Homepage that directly link to pre-filtered search results according to their specimen type.

Detailed specimen page

Map

  • Short information in the tool tip by hovering over the points in the map
  • The points on the map link to the specimen pages detailed pages
  • Points on the map with multiple specimens at the same location link to data table in order to reach specimen pages.

Image Gallery

  • There could always be no image, but also multiple images per data record. Thus, the number of records do not represent the number of images.
  • Hovering over the thumbnail shows short information
  • Clicking on the thumbnail shows bigger images, but only of the current result page. Each image with a link to original image URI and detailed specimen page

GeoCASe API

GeoCASe has a public API endpoint https://api.geocase.eu that can be used to obtain data Earth Science specimen data directly in machine-readable JSON format. The API is based on the OpenAPI standard.

How to provide data?

Introduction

To ensure the most up-to-date information in GeoCASe portal, we perform regular automatic harvesting of data from institutional databases.

In order to make an institutional database part of the GeoCASe network and visible in the GeoCASe portal, installation of a special software that reads data in your database and outputs it into a standardised format is necessary. GeoCASe encourages usage of an XML-based ABCD-EFG data exchange format and the BioCASe Provider Software. In the future, usage of other data standards and formats such as DarwinCore will be possible. Setting up this software in your institutional server usually needs help from your database manager and IT department. After installation of the provider software in a server accessible from the internet, the institutional database needs to be “mapped” against the standard XML schema. The institution should ensure that only the data that can be made publicly accessible will be served for GeoCASe. 

For full technical documentation about the BioCASe Provider Software, including installation instructions, can be found at https://www.biocase.org/products/provider_software. 

Note that as the technology and standards used are compliant with data provision to GBIF, there is limited additional technical effort for publishing your fossil data in GBIF as well. 

Step-by-step tutorial

Please don’t hesitate to contact us for further advice. 

1. Installation of the BioCASe Provider Software

The BioCASe (Biological Collection Access Service) Provider Software mediates between the local data sources and the GeoCASe portal. It is used to connect to the local databases and maps the local data structures to the data standard schemes like ABCD-EFG. A data harvester queries the data from the BioCASe Provider Software in order to aggregate the requested information from multiple data sources.

The BioCASe Provider Software is easy to install and may be obtained from the BioCASe website. A very handy official installation guide is made available by BioCASe.

2. Establishing the Connection between BioCASe Provider Software and Local Data Source

As soon as the Installation of the BioCASe Provider Software is completed, the connection to the local data source may be established from within the program interface.

Please use the official documentation for further information.

3. Description of the Database Structure

The description of the database structure may be done from within the interface of the BioCASe Provider Software. This step is documented here.

4. Data Mapping

The GeoCASe portal makes use of the ABCDEFG-XML-Scheme (Access to Biological Collections Data Extended for Geosciences), which was developed for the project, extending the ABCD-XML-Scheme (Access to Biological Collections Data) that is used for data provision to GBIF (Global Biodiversity Information Facility) , but to allow for data provision of paleontological, geological and mineralogical concepts as well.

To map your database for use with the ABCDEFG-XML-Scheme, please refer to the official documentation.

Please take notice of the mandatory concepts, which have to be mapped for a successful registration with the GeoCASe portal.

Mandatory concepts on dataset level (metadata): 

Concept name

Short description

Dataset Title

Title of the dataset of several specimen records

Dataset ID

Unique identifier of the dataset

Content Contact

Name and email address of contact person (e.g. curator)

Technical Contact

Name and email address of technical contact (e.g. database manager)

Owner Institution

Name, address, logo of the collection holding institution (owner of dataset)

Owner Institution country

Country of the collection holding institution

Terms of Use / License

Terms of use and / or license statement for the datasets and images

Date of last modification

Date of the last modification of the dataset

Mandatory concepts on specimen level are:
Fos = Fossils, Min = Minerals, Rox = Rocks, Met = Meteorites
m = mandatory, r = recommended, o = optional

Short description

Fos

5. Establishing the Connection between BioCASe Provider Software and the GeoCASe Portal

For registration with the GeoCASe Portal, simply send the URL of your BioCASe Provider Software instance referring to your data source to geocase@mfn.berlin.

efg.html:
EFG

ABCDEFG (Access to Biological Collection Databases Extended for Geosciences) is an XML-Schema (Extensible Markup Language) developed for use with palaeontological, mineralogical and geological digitalized collection data.

It extends the ABCD-XML-Schema (Access to Biological Collection Databases) used by GBIF (Glocal Biodiversity Iformation Facility).

The ABCDEFG-XML-Schema is used to apply a mapping to the local data source and it is supported by the BioCASe Provider Software. This Software is easy to install and provides a very handy user interface for databse description and mapping. The BioCASe Provider Software mediates between the local data source and the GeoCASe Portal by sending and receiving XML documents.

ABCDEFG is proposed to the organisation of biodiversity information standards TDWG (Taxonomic Databases Working Group) as a data standard for geoscientific collections.

GeoCASe will be adopted by GBIF as soon as possible. The schema provides a general format for data exchange and retrieval for geoscientific collections. It does not replace an individual database management software.

The BioCASe Provider Software may be obtained from https://biocase.org/products/provider_software/.

For further information on ABCD visit the TDWG Terms Wiki page https://www.tdwg.org/standards/abcd/.

For further information on the ABCD Extension for Geosciences (EFG) see Petersen et al. 2018 (pdf) or download the ABCDEFG-XML-Schema documentation which is also embedded below.

Open in new Window/Tab
ABCDEFG Schema Documentation:

access.html:
Terms of Use

Using data available through the GeoCASe network requires agreeing with the following:

  • The quality and completeness of data cannot be guaranteed.
  • Users employ these data at their own risk.
  • Users shall respect restrictions of access to sensitive data.
  • Users must publicly acknowledge, in conjunction with the use of the data, the data providers whose biodiversity data they have used.
  • Data providers may require additional attribution of specific collections within their institution.
  • Users must comply with additional terms and conditions of use set by the data provider. Where these exist they will be available through the metadata associated with the data. GeoCASe does not assert any intellectual property rights in the data that is made available through its network.
  • The data provider warrants that they have made the necessary agreements with the original owners of the data that it can make the data available through GeoCASe network.
  • The data provider makes reasonable efforts to ensure that the data they serve are accurate. Responsibility regarding the restriction of access to sensitive data resides with the data provider.
  • The data provider includes a stable and unique identifier in their data so that the owner of the data is known and for other necessary purposes.
  • GeoCASe is not liable or responsible, nor are its employees or contractors, for the data contents; or for any loss, damage, claim, cost or expense however it may arise, from an inability to use the GeoCASe network.

Disclaimer

Liability for Content

We make every effort to keep the information on our website current, but accept no liability whatsoever for the content provided. Pursuant to §7 par. 1 of TMG (German Tele-Media Act), the law limits our responsibility as a service provider to our own content on these Web pages.

According to §§8 to 10 of TMG, we are not obligated to monitor third party information provided or stored on our website. However, we shall promptly remove any content upon becoming aware that it violates the law. Our liability in such an instance shall commence at the time we become aware of the respective violation.

Liability for Links

Our site contains links to third-party Web sites. We have no influence whatsoever on the information on these Web sites and accept no guarantee for its correctness. The content of such third-party sites is the responsibility of the respective owners/providers.

At the time third-party Web sites were linked to ours, we found NO GROUNDS WHATSOEVER of any likely contravention of the law. We shall promptly delete a link upon becoming aware that it violates the law.

Copyright

The content of this data portal is aggregated from different data sources. We highly recommend data providers to assign open licences to their data in order to increase re-usability according to the FAIR principles (Wilkinson et al. 2016, https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2016.18).
However, the re-use of the data MUST have consideration for the individual licences and restrictions per dataset and data provider. If no licence is indicated by the data providers a full restriction (“all rights reserved”) must be assumed. Different licences for different data types (e.g. textual metadata and media files) within one dataset might be applied.

We are not accountable for any violation of copyrights caused by or at the data providers. The data providers provide the data and metadata on their own risk.

GeoCASe code is openly available at GitHub under GPL 3.0 License:

  • GeoCASe 2.0 portal software: https://github.com/geocollections/geocase-ui
  • GeoCASe thumbnail service: https://github.com/geocollections/geocase-thumbnail 
  • GeoCASe 1.0 infrastructure: https://github.com/geocollections/geocase-infrastructure

about.html:
What is GeoCASe?

GeoCASe stands for Geoscience Collections Access Service. It is a data network and web portal designed to make collections of minerals, rocks, meteorites and fossils held in museums and research institutions universally available online, in order to foster scientific research and collaboration internationally.

Data for GeoCASe network are provided by individual museums and research institutions, most commonly via the BioCASe Provider Software using XML-based data exchange standards ABCD (Access to Biological Collections Data) and ABCD-EFG (ABCD Extension for Geosciences; see Petersen et al. 2018). GeoCASe service “harvests” these data sources, stores the records in index and makes them easily accessible and searchable from a single user interface. GeoCASe aims to become the Earth Science counterpart of GBIF, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility used by thousands of institutions and researchers.

The initial version of GeoCASe was built at the Museum für Naturkunde, Berlin, as part of SYNTHESYS project in 2007. Development of an upgraded version, GeoCASE 2.0, started in 2020 by the Museum für Naturkunde and Tallinn University of Technology under coordination of the CETAF ESG (Consortium of European Taxonomic Facilities, Earth Science Group). Being a product of CETAF, which is a well established cohesive community of European Natural Science research institutes containing a wide-range of expertise in taxonomy, training, data standards and taxonomy, ensures that GeoCASe is reliable and sustainable in serving the needs of the wider community. GeoCASe will also become aligned with the DiSSCo Research Infrastructure. 

GeoCASe is currently managed by the ‘GeoCASe advisory board’ who are responsible for the development, maintenance, promotion and quality control of the portal.

partners_and_providers.html:
Partners

  • CETAF General Secretariat, Belgium
  • Meise Botanic Garden, Belgium
  • Museum für Naturkunde Berlin, Germany
  • National Museums Scotland, United Kingdom
  • National Museum, Prague, Czech republic, Czech Republic
  • Natural History Museum Vienna, Austria
  • Royal Museum of Central Africa, Belgium
  • State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart, Germany
  • Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia
  • Finnish Museum of Natural History, Finland
  • Naturalis Biodiversity Center, The Netherlands

Related Initiatives and Organizations

GeoCASe uses the BioCASe technology provided by Botanic Garden and Botanical Museum Berlin (BGBM) and the data standards ratified by TDWG in order to be compatible with GBIF as well.

It is officially supported by the CETAF and aligns its services in close collaboration with the DiSSCo Research Infrastructure.

cookiePolicy.introduction: See veebileht kasutab küpsiseid. Veebilehe kasutamist jätkates nõustute küpsiste kasutamisega
cookiePolicy.title: Küpsisepoliitika
cookiePolicy.text: Veebilehe külastajate andmeid kasutatakse ainult mitteisikustatud statistiliseks analüüsiks ning lehekülje funktsionaalsuse parandamiseks. Andmeid ei edastada kolmandatele osapooltele.

seo.description: GeoCASe is a data network and web portal designed to make collections of minerals, rocks, meteorites and fossils held in museums and research institutions universally available online.
